source.name: London Recycles / London Borough Councils
source.notes: Based on London Recycles and typical London borough recycling guidelines. Services vary slightly by borough. Food waste goes in grey food caddy. Aerosol cans NOT accepted in recycling in most boroughs.

materials.name: Glass bottles
notes: All colours of glass bottles are accepted
Labels can be left on
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass or drinking glasses
Don't include window glass or mirrors
Don't include perfume or nail varnish bottles

materials.name: Glass jars
notes: All colours of glass jars are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include Pyrex or heat-resistant glass
Don't include ceramics or crockery

materials.name: Newspapers
notes: Do not shred — shredded paper is not accepted in the recycling bin
commonMistakes: Don't shred newspapers before recycling
Don't include if soaked or heavily soiled

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Glossy paper is fine to recycle
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic wrapper — put that in general waste

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Remove any polystyrene or bubble wrap
Place in recycling bin or beside it if too large
notes: Flatten to save space in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes soiled with food or grease
Don't include polystyrene packing inside

materials.name: Cardboard packaging
notes: Includes multipacks sleeves, biscuit box inserts, etc.
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated card
Don't include grease-soaked card

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Squash the bottle to save space
notes: Lids should stay on the bottle
No need to remove labels
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic bags or film
Don't include bottles that contained chemicals or motor oil

materials.name: Plastic milk bottles
notes: One of the most commonly recycled items in the UK
commonMistakes: Don't leave milk residue — give it a quick rinse

materials.name: Plastic pots, tubs, and trays
instructions: Rinse and scrape out food residue
notes: Most London boroughs accept pots, tubs and trays
Check with your borough if unsure about black plastic trays
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene trays
Don't include heavily food-soiled trays

materials.name: Plastic food containers
notes: Rigid plastic containers are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene containers
Don't include film lids — peel those off and bin them

materials.name: Food and drink cartons (Tetra Paks)
notes: Includes Tetra Pak and similar layered cartons
Most London boroughs now accept these
commonMistakes: Don't worry about rinsing — just empty them

materials.name: Aluminium cans
notes: Aluminium is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with aerosol cans — aerosols are NOT accepted in most London boroughs

materials.name: Steel tins and cans
notes: Use a magnet to check — steel is magnetic, aluminium is not
Labels can be left on
commonMistakes: Don't include paint tins or chemical tins

materials.name: Envelopes
instructions: Plastic windows are fine — no need to remove them
notes: Windowed envelopes are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include padded or bubble-lined envelopes — those go in general waste

materials.name: Greeting cards
instructions: Remove any glitter, ribbons, or embellishments
notes: Plain cards are fine; glittery parts must be removed or card goes in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cards with glitter still attached
Don't include musical cards with batteries

materials.name: Cereal boxes
instructions: Remove the inner plastic bag and put it in general waste
Place flattened box in recycling bin
notes: The inner plastic liner is not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag

materials.name: Toilet and kitchen roll tubes
instructions: Flatten and place in recycling bin
notes: Cardboard tubes are easily recycled
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with paper towels themselves — paper towels go in general waste

materials.name: Cardboard egg boxes
notes: Cardboard egg boxes only — not polystyrene or plastic ones
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene egg boxes — those go in general waste

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles
notes: Trigger spray nozzles can be left on
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles that are still partly full

materials.name: Writing and printing paper
notes: Staples are fine — they are removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't shred paper — shredded paper is not accepted

materials.name: Wrapping paper (non-metallic)
instructions: Scrunch test: if it stays scrunched, it can be recycled
Remove all tape, ribbons, and bows
notes: Metallic or glittery wrapping paper cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil or glittery wrapping paper — that goes in general waste
Don't include ribbons or bows

materials.name: Paper bags
notes: Remove any plastic handles if present
commonMistakes: Don't include wax-coated or grease-soaked paper bags

materials.name: Phone books and directories
notes: Can be recycled whole — no need to tear pages out

materials.name: Biscuit and sweet tins
notes: Metal tins used for biscuits, chocolates, and sweets are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic tray insert — put that in general waste

materials.name: Yoghurt pots
instructions: Peel off the foil lid and recycle separately
notes: Most London boroughs accept yoghurt pots
commonMistakes: Don't leave food residue inside

materials.name: Margarine and butter tubs
notes: Plastic tubs from spreads are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't leave a thick layer of residue

materials.name: Plastic ready meal trays
instructions: Remove film lid and put in general waste
notes: Check with your borough about black plastic trays — some do not accept them
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic film lid
Don't include polystyrene trays

materials.name: Drink cans
notes: Both aluminium and steel drink cans are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with aerosol cans

materials.name: Food tins
notes: No need to remove labels
commonMistakes: Don't include paint or chemical tins

materials.name: Food scraps and leftovers
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
Use a caddy liner (compostable or newspaper)
notes: All cooked and uncooked food is accepted in the food caddy
Collected weekly in most boroughs
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the recycling bin
Don't use plastic bags as caddy liners

materials.name: Tea bags
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: Most tea bags contain a small amount of plastic, but they are accepted in food waste
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
Paper filters can go in too
notes: Do not include coffee pods — those go in general waste unless specialist recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include coffee pods (Nespresso, Dolce Gusto, etc.)

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable peelings
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: All fruit and vegetable waste including peelings, cores, and tops
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: Crush them to save space if you like
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Stale bread and pastries
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: Mouldy bread is fine — it all gets composted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin
Don't include packaging

materials.name: Meat, fish, and bones
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: Both raw and cooked meat/fish accepted in food waste caddy
Bones are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin or general waste if food caddy is available

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: Small amounts of dairy are fine in the food caddy
commonMistakes: Don't pour liquids directly in — use a caddy liner

materials.name: Cooked rice, pasta, and noodles
instructions: Place in grey food waste caddy
notes: All cooked starchy foods accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic bags and wrappers
notes: Some supermarkets have carrier bag collection points for soft plastics
NOT accepted in kerbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — plastic bags jam sorting machinery

materials.name: Polystyrene and styrofoam
instructions: Break up large pieces to fit
notes: Not recyclable at kerbside in any London borough
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Nappies and sanitary products
notes: Never place in the recycling bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin
Don't put in the food waste caddy

materials.name: Shredded paper
notes: Shredded paper fibres are too short to recycle and jam machinery
Can be home-composted if you have a composter
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — it jams sorting equipment

materials.name: Food-soiled packaging
notes: Grease and food contaminate paper recycling
Tear off the clean parts and recycle those
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy pizza boxes in recycling — tear off and recycle the clean lid if possible

materials.name: Paper towels and tissues
notes: Paper fibres are too degraded and contaminated to recycle
Can be home-composted if uncontaminated
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Cling film
notes: Not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Crisp packets and sweet wrappers
notes: These are made of mixed materials (plastic and metallic film) and cannot be recycled at kerbside
Some specialist schemes (e.g., Terracycle) accept these
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — they look metallic but are not aluminium

materials.name: Bubble wrap
instructions: Or take to a supermarket carrier bag collection point
notes: Not accepted in kerbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Broken crockery and ceramics
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling — never mix them
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — they ruin glass recycling

materials.name: Drinking glasses and Pyrex
notes: Drinking glasses and Pyrex have different melting points to bottle glass and contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — different type of glass to bottles/jars

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in general waste bin or take to household waste recycling centre
notes: Different composition to bottle/jar glass
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Wet wipes
notes: Most wet wipes contain plastic and are not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't flush wet wipes — they cause sewer blockages
Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Cotton wool and cotton buds
notes: Even if the stick is paper, used cotton buds go in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't flush cotton buds
Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Compostable and biodegradable packaging
notes: Compostable packaging is NOT accepted in recycling or food waste
It requires industrial composting facilities not available via kerbside collection
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — it contaminates plastic recycling
Don't put in the food waste caddy

materials.name: Aluminium foil
notes: Most London boroughs do NOT accept foil in kerbside recycling
Check with your specific borough
commonMistakes: Don't assume foil is always recyclable — in London it usually isn't at kerbside

materials.name: Aerosol cans
notes: Most London boroughs do NOT accept aerosols in kerbside recycling
Check with your specific borough — some are now accepting them
commonMistakes: Don't assume aerosols are recyclable — check your borough
Never puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a battery collection point at supermarkets or council buildings
Never put in any household bin
notes: Batteries can cause fires in bin lorries and at recycling centres
Most supermarkets and shops have free battery collection points
commonMistakes: Never put batteries in household bins — fire risk
Don't throw away rechargeable batteries — recycle them

materials.name: Electronics and electricals
instructions: Take to a household waste recycling centre (HWRC)
Some boroughs offer kerbside collection for small electricals
notes: Under WEEE regulations, retailers must accept old items when you buy replacements
Never put in household bins
commonMistakes: Don't put in any household bin
Don't put in the recycling bin

materials.name: Vapes and e-cigarettes
instructions: Take to a vape recycling point or household waste recycling centre
Never put in any household bin
notes: Vapes contain lithium batteries and are a serious fire risk in bins and bin lorries
Many shops now have vape collection points
commonMistakes: Never put vapes in any household bin — fire risk
Don't throw disposable vapes in the rubbish

materials.name: Paint and varnish
instructions: Take to household waste recycling centre (HWRC)
Or donate usable paint to Community RePaint schemes
notes: Never pour paint down the drain
Dried-out paint tins (fully empty) can sometimes go in general waste
commonMistakes: Don't put in any household bin
Don't pour down drains or toilets

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to household waste recycling centre
LED bulbs: take to HWRC or electricals recycling point
Old-style incandescent and halogen bulbs: general waste bin
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury and must not go in household bins
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in the recycling bin
Don't put any light bulb in the glass recycling

materials.name: Textiles and clothes
instructions: Donate to charity shops if in good condition
Use textile banks or kerbside collection
Damaged textiles can go to household waste recycling centre
notes: Do NOT put in the recycling bin
Even damaged clothes can be recycled — don't bin them
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling bin — they jam machinery
Don't put good clothes in general waste — donate or recycle

recycle: Glass bottles and jars (remove metal lids)
Plastic pots, tubs, trays, and containers
Food and drink cartons / Tetra Paks (squash, keep lids on)
Aluminium and steel tins and cans
compost: All food waste in grey food waste caddy
Tea bags, coffee grounds and filters
trash: Plastic bags, wrappers, cling film, bubble wrap

recycle: Plastic bags and film — they jam sorting machinery
Food waste — use the grey food waste caddy
Textiles and clothes — use charity shops or textile banks

tips: If in doubt, leave it out!
Squash plastic bottles and cartons — keep lids on
Rinse containers; they don't need to be spotless
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space
Remove metal lids from glass bottles and jars
Never bag your recycling — empty items loose into the bin
Shredded paper cannot be recycled — put in general waste
Vapes and batteries cause fires in bin lorries — take to collection points
Supermarkets accept carrier bags and soft plastics
Services vary by borough — check your council's website

locations.name: London Borough Household Waste Recycling Centres (HWRCs)
locations.notes: Each borough operates its own HWRC. Check your council website for locations and booking requirements.

locations.name: Supermarket Soft Plastics Collection
locations.notes: Most major supermarkets (Tesco, Sainsbury's, Co-op, Waitrose) have front-of-store collection points for soft plastics.
